title: Want to help fight hunger in Boston? Here are 5 ways to do it.
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Support the Greater Boston Food Bank; $3 donations provide two meals through partnerships with over 600 organizations.
Participate in the Allston-Brighton Food Train to donate and deliver food to assigned families in November.
Volunteer at East Boston Community Soup Kitchen to prepare meals or donate kitchen supplies, groceries, and clothing.

title: As injuries linger, Patriots rookie Kyle Williams could be poised for breakout opportunity
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Kayshon Boutte out with hamstring injury; Kyle Williams could see increased play time for Patriots vs. Buccaneers.
Williams, a 2025 third-round pick, has caught only two passes this season, but coaches are optimistic about his progress.
Patriots offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels praises Williams' readiness and potential to step up in Boutte's absence.

title: What songs are on your ‘divorce playlist’?
author: Meredith Goldstein
bullets: Meredith Goldstein differentiates divorce songs from breakup songs, noting they focus on logistics and emotional aspects of marriage.
Favorite divorce songs include Sinead O’Connor’s 'The Last Day of Our Acquaintance' and Lily Allen's 'West End Girl'.
Goldstein invites readers to share their favorite divorce songs that suggest closure or moving on.

title: 10 days after their ugliest loss of year, Bruins are looking like a very different team
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Boston Bruins improved their record with five consecutive wins after a rough start earlier in the season.
Key players like Marat Khusnutdinov and Charlie McAvoy have been instrumental in the Bruins' recent victories.
Head coach Marco Sturm emphasizes a strong defensive mindset as the team adapts to his new system.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com offers a quiz to test knowledge of recent Greater Boston news.
The news quiz covers trending stories in the Greater Boston area.
Peter Chianca, Boston.com editor since 2019, oversees the news quiz initiative.

title: Tripadvisor to cut 20% of staff amid internal restructuring
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Tripadvisor plans to cut 20% of its workforce as part of merging Tripadvisor and Viator operations.
The restructuring includes an $85 million cost-savings program focusing on experience-driven growth and AI integration.
The layoffs, affecting around 600 employees, come amid pressure from investor Starboard Value for strategic changes.

title: An abandoned tent has spurred a hiking mystery in New Hampshire
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: An abandoned tent was discovered at the Valley Way tent site in New Hampshire's White Mountains on Oct. 26.
The tent contained wet gear, food, and a set of car keys, but no missing hikers were reported.
Authorities shared the case on social media for leads; no vehicle matched the keys found at the site.

title: Local obituary: Susan Hurley, 62, former Patriots cheerleader who founded CharityTeams
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Susan Hurley, 62, founded CharityTeams, raising $42 million for nonprofits through athletic events, particularly Boston Marathon training.
Former Patriots cheerleader and longtime marathon trainer Susan Hurley passed away after a battle with ovarian cancer.
A Celebration of Life will occur November 8 at Waters Church Norwood, followed by a reception at Gillette Stadium.

title: Market Basket launches its own beer — here’s where to buy it
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Market Basket launched its own lager in collaboration with Vermont's Zero Gravity Beer.
The 'More For Your Dollar' lager 12-pack sells for $12.99 at selected Market Basket locations.
The beer is available in Market Basket outlets in Massachusetts, Maine, and New Hampshire.

title: As SJC mulls involvement in public defender work stoppage, here’s where things stand
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Over 900 defendants remain unrepresented despite a state-approved pay raise for public defenders in Massachusetts.
The Supreme Judicial Court is considering whether it can order temporary pay raises for court-appointed attorneys amid a work stoppage.
State legislators approved a $20 hourly pay increase for bar advocates, but the crisis of unrepresented defendants persists.
